title: British yacht industry welcomes stability amid Brexit negotiations
description:
(29 Sep 2017) LEAD IN:
Forget Brexit woes, the UK's super yacht industry is riding a wave of success, recently posting record revenue figures of 615 million British pounds (approx. $823 million USD).
But analysts say those calm seas might turn to rough waters should Britain edge towards a clean break from the EU, or so-called "hard Brexit".

STORY-LINE:
Britain's yacht industry is in a confident mood at the Monaco Yacht Show, an annul four-day glitzy sail fest.
According to figures, recently released by Super Yacht UK, the UK's super yacht sector has remained buoyant, posting its fifth consecutive year of growth.
In 2016, the industry grew 1.7 percent to record figures of 615 million British pounds (approx. $823 million USD).
That's despite the EU referendum and recent UK general election.
Part of that success might be attributed to the weak pound following Britain's leave vote last June, it was dubbed the "Brexit discount".
"They're having a great time at the moment," says Boat International's Stewart Campbell.
"We've just seen some figures from Super Yacht UK, the trade association, the British super yacht industry has had its best year ever. So yards like Princess, Sunseeker, Fairline, Oyster, Pendennis down in Falmouth, they're going okay because suddenly forego buyers are finding their products are a lot cheaper."
Plymouth-based Princess Yachts is showcasing three yachts in Monaco, including this 35-metre White Dream that was launched this year.
Princess executive chairman Antony Sheriff claims recent success shouldn't just be attributed to a weak pound.
"It's a transient thing," he says. 
"You can call it the Brexit discount, but I like to think for the three years previous it was the euro discount because we're actually just at the same euro to pound exchange rate that we were three years ago. 
"So our euro competitors had a short term benefit and now we're back to normality, let's say."
Princess prides itself on crafting every single part of its luxurious yachts in-house, at its Plymouth shipyards.
What might prove a challenge to the yacht maker would be a clean break, or so-called "Hard Brexit", from the 28 bloc EU.
"That would be very bad news," admits Sheriff. 
"We are very much a global company, we sell our boats literally all over the world, we source components from all over the world and natural blockages which would see components held up in customs with tariffs really is not in the interests of competition.
"And it's not in the interest of running a high-quality business and it's certainly not in the interest of maintaining high employment in the UK."
"Uncertainty is bad for business generally and consumer confidence," says Howard Pridding from British Marine.
"But we are strong at the moment, we are optimistic and we will continue to do the business while politicians talk about Brexit."
Poole-based Sunseeker Yachts is also exhibiting in Monaco, showcasing a total of three yachts, including this 35-metre 116. 
"Buying a luxury yacht is a 100 percent discretionary purchase," says Sunseeker CEO Phil Popham. 
"No one needs yachts, it's about their leisure life, it's about their private life and although the weakness of the pound has in the short term made us more competitive against some of our foreign based manufacturers, foreign based competitors, it's not an impulse purchase and so I don' think the impact of the weak pound is going to be beneficial for a long period of time."
Last week, British Prime Minister Theresa May said Britain was prepared to abide by European Union rules and pay in to the bloc's coffers for two years after leaving the EU in March 2019.
"What we really do want is a level of certainty and stability," he says. 
The annual Monaco Yacht Show runs 27-30 September.
